subject: Use flat encapsulation type for external network
commit_message:
Use flat encapsulation type for external network

Otherwise the default, VXLAN, type is used, which makes the router to
set MTU for its gateway port that is lower than br-ex MTU. Then, packets
that are initiated from br-ex but don't fit thru the VXLAN MTU tagged
port are silently dropped, making ssh connectivity fail on key exchange.

The change will make devstack to pass PUBLIC_PHYSICAL_NETWORK as a
'neutron net-create' --provider:physical_network= argument. Since
linuxbridge jobs configure the physical network alias to 'default'
instead of 'public' (that is default for devstack and all ovs based
jobs), we also need to match it in localrc.

This should solve test failures accessing floating IPs with ssh that we
see in linuxbridge multinode grenade jobs.

There is a patch for devstack that enables the behaviour by default:
Id20e67aba5dfd2044b82c700f41c6e648b529430.  Since devstack has branches,
we would need to backport that patch into stable/mitaka to make grenade
job apply the new setting to networks created on the old side of the
cloud. It's easier to enforce it for all jobs in devstack-gate.

Related-Bug: #1605271
Change-Id: I2c62afd71517cebaf5b34cc3d9eac6cbe4cbda2c

commit_message:
Revert "lb-agent: ensure tap mtu is the same as physical device"

Conflicts:
	neutron/plugins/linuxbridge/agent/linuxbridge_neutron_agent.py
	neutron/tests/unit/plugins/linuxbridge/agent/test_linuxbridge_neutron_agent.py

This hack was used to copy MTU from physical bridges to tap devices to
support Jumbo frames. Now that we have proper MTU behaviour in interface
drivers, this is not needed.

Even back in Liberty times when it was introduced, there was no real
need to get Jumbo aware MTU on tap devices. This could have been
achieved by setting network_device_mtu on Nova side in addition to
Neutron.

This behaviour makes all efforts of the interface driver to set the
correct network MTU on all ports ineffective. It breaks multinode
grenade linuxbridge job, among other things.

We should backport it to Mitaka too if we want to fix linuxbridge
multinode grenade for Newton.

Handle TypeError when disabling host service

is called to change service status of a host from

a TypeError occurs while concatenating disabled_reason with

subject: Enable 2 or more input for a storlet app
commit_message:
Enable 2 or more input for a storlet app

Some application may want to get multiple objects for storlet exectuion.

For example, we'd like to get the difference from text-A and text-B,
both exist in the storage side. Currently, storlet can not reach out the
use case so that we have to retrieve the objects to local by hand, and
then should check the difference. However, imagine storlet can take
multiple input, what we should do is just a making an application to
return the diff from 2 input stream.

What's new:

This patch adds a new API header "X-Storlet-Extra-Resources" in the
request which enables multiple input streams to a storlet app.
X-Storlet-Extra-Resoureces allows the value formatted as a csv consists
of swift path ('/container/object') that is similar with swift copy
request. Note that currently only the path container + object is allowed.
(including account path is not yet supported) If you want to more
streams, you can add more paths to the csv. The object streams will be
appeared as other streams behind of the main stream. (main PUT or GET)
i.e. if you specified 2 extra streams in the header, 3 streams (1 main
and 2 extras) will be supplied for your apps.

Example is like:
GET /con/main
X-Storlet-Extra-Resources: /con/oA, /con2/oB

your app get StorletInputStream Array like,
[stream(/con/main), stream(/con/oA), stream(/con2/oB)]

How it works:

Storlet middleware will handle the X-Storlet-Extra-Resoureces header.
If it is comming from, storlet handler will try to get the object(s)
from backend storage and set the stream(s) into the storlet app via SBus
protocol. Each stream instance is just a input stream as well as main
object stream we are currently using for storlet apps.

Note that currently the extra resources is designed for running only
proxy-server. To run on the object-server, we need more complicated
works how to get the extra resources and this version *may* not have the
ristriction to prevent to run that app in an object-server
unfortunately.

- More tests with/without X-Storlet-Run-On-Proxy

subject: Check 'thin_provisioning' in extra specs
commit_message:
Check 'thin_provisioning' in extra specs

Currently in the capacity filter and weigher of the scheduler,
we use the logic to evaluate whether there is enough capacity
to thin provision a share on a backend if the driver reports
thin_provisioning to be True. However, a driver may be able to
support both thin and thick provisioning. The logic does not
check whether the user wants the share to be provisioned as thin
or not.

In this patch, we check 'thin_provisioning' in extra specs of the
share type and decide whether to use the logic for thin or thick.
In the following two cases, we will use the thin logic:
1) 'thin_provisioning' is not set in extra specs. This is to
   provide backward compatibility.
2) 'thin_provisioning' is set in extra specs and it is
   '<is> True' or 'True'.

To provision a thick share on a backend that supports both
thin and thick, set one of the following in extra specs:
    {'thin_provisioning': 'False'}
    {'thin_provisioning': '<is> False'}
    {'capabilities:thin_provisioning': 'False'}
    {'capabilities:thin_provisioning': '<is> False'}

DocImpact

subject: Fix IPv6 router advertisements with multiple networks
commit_message:
Fix IPv6 router advertisements with multiple networks

This involves a significant rework of the Calico DHCP agent,
specifically to run an instance of Dnsmasq for each Neutron network that
is in use on the compute host where the DHCP agent is running (as the
reference Neutron DHCP agent does); instead of running just a single
instance of Dnsmasq for all of the Neutron networks that are in use on
the compute host.

The Calico DHCP agent has previously been using (what it thought was) an
optimization / simplification compared to the reference Neutron DHCP
agent: it runs a single Dnsmasq instance provisioned with the collated
subnet information for all Neutron networks that are relevant to
instances hosted by the local compute node; whereas the reference
Neutron DHCP agent runs a Dnsmasq instance _per Neutron network_,
provisioned only with the subnet information for that network.

Calico's simplification works correctly for DHCPv4 and DHCPv6, but
unfortunately not for IPv6 Router Advertisements (RAs): the effect of
the simplification is that the same RA, including router prefixes for
all of the Neutron networks that some local instances use, is sent to
every local TAP interface.  This means that:

- a port that is attached to a network without any IPv6 subnets will
  still get IPv6 routing information

- if different local ports are attached to networks with different
  IPv6 subnets, they will receive each other's routing information as
  well as their own.

Therefore this commit removes that simplification, and now the Calico
DHCP agent will run a separate Dnsmasq instance for each relevant
Neutron network.

The main constituents of this change are:

- adding each subnet's network ID to the information about that subnet
  that the Calico ML2 driver stores in etcd

- populating and maintaining the NetworkCache with multiple NetModels,
  reflecting the true Neutron network/subnet structure, instead of with
  a single collated NetModel

- instructing each Dnsmasq to listen on precisely the relevant TAP
  interfaces, instead of on a wildcard ('tap*').

Sem-Ver: bugfix

subject: improve pylint; generate errors and config in sorted order
commit_message:
improve pylint; generate errors and config in sorted order

Since the config is not in a deterministic order makes it hard to
compare two config's and see what changed. Personally, I'm not
positive I understand this use-case; i.e. you have an existing config
file, you save it, and then rebuild and then diff the two files. I'd
have thought you'd just run check and the output of the tool was the
diff.

I however do see the value in sorting the file so that when someone
submits a change that includes a change to the config, reviewers can
see more easily what the change is doing.

Similarly, the output from pylint (errors) are generated one file at a
time and os.walk makes no guarantee of deterministic order. So we
should collect all errors (across all files) and then print an ordered
list for human consumption.

The intent is also to make pylint voting soon (in master). the changes
to contributing.rst and tox.ini are to make that easier. The config
file has also been sorted in place.

This change was motivated by an email exchange with Peter so I am
marking him as a co-conspirator.

The line numbers were removed from the tools/trove-pylint.config file
as these would change whenever the line numbers in the file changed
(since they are currently not being used in the comparison; they can
be re-added if deemed necessary at the cost of having every 'rebuild'
run create a different file).

This patch reworks the NODE_DELETE action logic so that:

1. adjustment of desired capacity (when needed) is based on the current

2. cluster's status will be re-evaluated if the node belongs to a
   cluster and its do_delete() method has been invoked;
3. the reduction of desired_capacity will be performed only when (a)
   node is not orphan; (b) action was from a RPC request; (c) reduction

subject: yum-minimal: Disable excludes when installing pkg manager
commit_message:
yum-minimal: Disable excludes when installing pkg manager

Because we are using the building platform's "yum" to do the initial
install into the chroot, it is affected by the base-system's
/etc/yum.conf.

pip-and-virtaulenv in I82acb865378a0fa5903a6267bfcee0e2962eced0 added
"exclude=python-pip..." in /etc/yum.conf to stop the package manager
overwriting the installed pip.  Now our CI images have built with
this, we are now picking up this exclude on centos.  Since on F24
dnf->python->python-pip we end up failing to build the the chroot
because python-pip can not be satisifed.  In a general sense, however,
this could be caused by any configuration put into /etc/yum.conf that
is incompatible with installing into the chroot.

yum has the option to disable all excludes which is used here.  This
seems to be the best way to isolate the chroot install from any
excludes that may have been done on the base system for various
reasons.  I did consider using a completely separate yum.conf we ship
with dib ... but let's start simple.

This should fix the current gate failures on centos

Distributed cache namespace to invalidate regions

dogpile.cache's region invalidation is not designed to work across
processes. This patch enables distributed invalidation of keys in a
region.

Instead of using a static cache key, we use the original cache key
and append a dynamic value to it. This value is looked up in
memcached using the region name as a key. So anytime the value of
the region key changes the cache keys in that region are
effectively invalidated.

subject: Fixes password created_at errors due to the server_default
commit_message:
Fixes password created_at errors due to the server_default

Migration 002 sets the password created_at column to a TIMESTAMP type
with a server_default=sql.func.now(). There are a couple problems
that have been uncovered with this change:
* We cannot guarantee that func.now() will generate a UTC timestamp.
* For some older versions of MySQL, the default TIMESTAMP column will
automatically be updated when other columns are updated:
https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.5/en/timestamp-initialization.html

This patch fixes the problem by recreating the password created_at
column back to a DateTime type without a server_default:
1) Drop and recreate the created_at column
2) Update the created_at value
3) Set the created_at column as not nullable

subject: Add a function to upgrade from full HA to NG HA
commit_message:
Add a function to upgrade from full HA to NG HA

This is the initial work to have a function that migrates a full HA
architecture as deployed in Mitaka to the HA architecture as deployed in
Newton where only a few resources are managed by pacemaker.

The sequence is the following:
1) We remove the desired services from pacemaker's control. The services
   at this point are still running normally via the systemd service as
   invoked by pacemaker
2) We do a "systemctl stop <service>" on all controllers for all the
   services that were removed from pacemaker's control. We do this to make
   sure that during the yum upgrade, the %post sections that call
   "systemctl try-restart" do not take ages, because at this point during
   the upgrade rabbit is down. The only exceptions are "openstack-core"
   and "delay" which are dummy pacemaker resources that do not exist on
   the system
3) We do a "systemctl start <service>" on all nodes for all the services
   mentioned above.

We should probably merge this patch only when newton has branched as it
is very specific to the M/N upgrade.

subject: Switching expression order within if condition
commit_message:
Switching expression order within if condition

In nova/cmd/manage.py, on line 294 [1] there is the following line:

  if value['limit'] < 0 or value['limit'] is None:

The problem occurs when value['limit'] is None, as this line tries
to compare None (object) with an integer value.

This comparsion is totally okay (without errors) in Python27.
But, if you run this on Python34, a TypError is raised:

  TypeError: unorderable types: NoneType() < int()

It is simply fixed with swapping the two expressions within the
if condition. Now if value['limit'] is None, the first expression
becomes true and second one does not get evaluated.

subject: Allow using TempURLs for deploy images
commit_message:
Allow using TempURLs for deploy images

when iPXE is enabled, it is possible for the bootloader to download
the deploy kernel and ramdisk directly from Swift TempURL instead of
downloading them to conductor and serving from local HTTP server.

This patch adds the required logic and a new config option
`ipxe_use_swift` (default False), setting which to True enables
using Swift TempURLs for deploy ramdisk and kernel.

Note that local caching and serving for kernel and ramdisk of user image
is still performed for partition images that require non-local boot,
as moving those to use TempURLs will make it impossible for the user
to reboot the instance when TempURLs time out or image is deleted from
Glance/Swift.

Change-Id: I106cc6148c329e784bfbb5019fdfeb0509a9de09
Closes-Bug: #1526404
